stem: The nurse is analyzing laboratory and clinical findings for two clients with pituitary imbalances. Match each finding with either SIADH (Syndrome of Inappropriate ADH) or Diabetes Insipidus (DI).

rows.text: Low Serum Sodium (Hyponatremia) (<135 mEq/L) due to water retention.
Excessive polyuria (400 mL/hr) and profound thirst.
Fluid restriction is the primary nursing intervention.

rationale.correct: ADH (Antidiuretic Hormone) controls water 'holding'. (r1, r2, & r5) SIADH = Too many 'Hold' signals; the body keeps water, diluting the blood (Low Sodium) and concentrating the urine (High SG). (r3 & r4) DI = Too few 'Hold' signals; the body dumps water, leading to massive pee (Polyuria) and dilute urine.
rationale.incorrect: Diabetes Insipidus is NOT related to blood glucose levels; it is a water-regulation problem.
clinicalPearls: The most dangerous complication of SIADH is cerebral edema due to rapid hyponatremia. Monitor for seizure activity.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember 'DI = Dry Inside'. The patient is losing all their water. SIADH = 'Soaked Inside'. The patient is keeping all their water.

mnemonic.title: S-v-D
mnemonic.expansion: SIADH (Soaked Inside, S-alt Low). DI (Dry Inside, D-rain the body).

reviewUnits.heading: ADH Imbalances
reviewUnits.body: Nurses monitor hourly I/O and daily weights. DI is often treated with Desmopressin (Synthetic ADH). SIADH is managed with fluid restriction and sometimes 3% saline (hypertonic).
